thread.title: DraftKings Cut Its Ties With Poker
thread.title_full: DraftKings Cut Its Ties With Poker - The New York Times

author: Jacqueline Williams
title: DraftKings Cut Its Ties With Poker
text:
The daily fantasy sports company DraftKings has ended its partnership with the World Series of Poker amid rising questions over whether fantasy sports, which are unregulated, should be considered gambling.
DraftKings has had a prominent advertising presence at World Series of Poker events and offered exclusive World Series of Poker-branded contests that awarded winners free entries to the final poker tournament.
But with regulators and law enforcement officials on several fronts scrutinizing the daily fantasy sports industry , DraftKings is moving to distance itself from poker, which is considered gambling and is heavily regulated in the United States.
Last week, the Nevada Gaming Control Board ruled that daily fantasy sports should be considered gambling and ordered the websites DraftKings and FanDuel to suspend operations in the state until the companies and their employees received gambling licenses there.
Continue reading the main story Related Coverage Cash Drops and Keystrokes: The Dark Reality of Sports Betting and Daily Fantasy Games OCT. 15, 2015 Inquiry Finds No Wrongdoing by DraftKings Employee, the Company Says OCT. 19, 2015 Nevada Says It Will Treat Daily Fantasy Sports Sites as Gambling OCT. 15, 2015 In Fantasy Sports, Signs of Insiders’ Edge OCT. 11, 2015 Scandal Erupts in Unregulated World of Fantasy Sports OCT. 5, 2015 “In light of last week’s news in Nevada, DraftKings asked us to cease any sponsorship activities around the remaining few W.S.O.P. events of the year, and we complied,” said Seth Palansky, a spokesman for the World Series of Poker.
Betting on fantasy sports, in which players assemble their own fantasy teams of athletes, is allowed in most states. That position is increasingly being questioned after fantasy companies began offering daily competitions, million-dollar prizes and other games that more closely resemble gambling.
DraftKings has also stopped offering its contest winners free entries to the final poker tournament, the company said Thursday night. The fantasy player Max Steinberg, one of the final nine poker players who will compete for $7.68 million next month, won his entry through a DraftKings league that had an entry fee of $27. Steinberg has worn the DraftKings logo throughout the event but is no longer affiliated with the company.
“This is a result of daily fantasy sports no longer being authorized in Nevada,” Sabrina Macias, a spokeswoman for DraftKings, said.
DraftKings became television’s top advertiser when it showed a commercial every minute and a half in the week leading up to the N.F.L. season, according to iSpot.tv , which tracks television advertising. Since then, the industry has been under siege, with investigators looking into whether employees, armed with inside information, exploited paying customers.
Daily fantasy sports operate under an exemption to the Unlawful Internet Gambling Enforcement Act of 2006, which outlawed online poker and sports betting.
